content.raw:
Tested multiple genomedata archive implementation using multipledatasets test by comparing the result of all 4 tracks in 1 genomedata archive vs all 4 tracks in 4 sep genomedata archives:

1 genomedata archive:

```
#!python

rachelc [ /scratch/segway-mixture-resubmit/test/multipledatasets ]$ cat test-20161110.7SoJ7g/traindir/log/segway.sh
## segway 1.4.2.dev0 run a3aac45ea79a11e6a052989096b2d04e at 2016-11-10 18:08:49.428876

cd "/scratch/segway-mixture-resubmit/test/multipledatasets/test-20161110.7SoJ7g"
"/scratch/software/bin/segway" "--cluster-opt=" "--include-coords=../include-coords.bed" "--mixture-components=3" "--track=testtrack1A,testtrack1B" "--track=testtrack2A,testtrack2B" "--num-labels=4" "train" "../full.genomedata" "traindir"
```

4 genomedata archives:

```
#!python

rachelc [ /scratch/segway-mixture-resubmit/test/multipledatasets ]$ cat test-20161110.TF1nfI/traindir/log/segway.sh
## segway 1.4.2.dev0 run 0d714f06a79711e6a184989096b2d04e at 2016-11-10 17:43:08.957713

cd "/scratch/segway-mixture-resubmit/test/multipledatasets/test-20161110.TF1nfI"
"/scratch/software/bin/segway" "--cluster-opt=" "--include-coords=../include-coords.bed" "--mixture-components=3" "--track=testtrack1A,testtrack1B" "--track=testtrack2A,testtrack2B" "--num-labels=4" "train" "../track1a.genomedata" "../track1b.genomedata" "../track2a.genomedata" "../track2b.genomedata" "traindir"

```

Resulting segmentation is the same:

```
#!python

rachelc [ /scratch/segway-mixture-resubmit/test/multipledatasets ]$ zdiff test-20161110.7SoJ7g/identifydir/segway.0.bed.gz test-20161110.TF1nfI/identifydir/segway.0.bed.gz 
1c1
< track autoScale=off description="segway 4-label segmentation of testtrack1A, testtrack1B, testtrack2A, testtrack2B" viewLimits=0:1 visibility=dense name=segway.e9ef3f30a79a11e69b0b989096b2d04e itemRgb=on
---
> track autoScale=off description="segway 4-label segmentation of testtrack1A, testtrack1B, testtrack2A, testtrack2B" viewLimits=0:1 visibility=dense name=segway.5439c0f8a79711e6914f989096b2d04e itemRgb=on
rachelc [ /scratch/segway-mixture-resubmit/test/multipledatasets ]$ zdiff test-20161110.7SoJ7g/identifydir/segway.1.bed.gz test-20161110.TF1nfI/identifydir/segway.1.bed.gz 
1c1
< track autoScale=off description="segway 4-label segmentation of testtrack1A, testtrack1B, testtrack2A, testtrack2B" viewLimits=0:1 visibility=dense name=segway.e9ef3f30a79a11e69b0b989096b2d04e itemRgb=on
---
> track autoScale=off description="segway 4-label segmentation of testtrack1A, testtrack1B, testtrack2A, testtrack2B" viewLimits=0:1 visibility=dense name=segway.5439c0f8a79711e6914f989096b2d04e itemRgb=on

```

Notably, this is without zscore though.

content.raw: @ericr86 Note that simpleseg is converges identically with ```MIX_PSEUDOCOUNTS=0``` and ```MIX_PSEUDOCOUNTS=100```, but I'm not sure if this is universally true/would still be true for all non-trivial cases.
content.html: @ericr86 Note that simpleseg is converges identically with MIX_PSEUDOCOUNTS=0 and MIX_PSEUDOCOUNTS=100, but I'm not sure if this is universally true/would still be true for all non-trivial cases.

content.raw:
```segway-internal``` is not public, but as per @mlibbrecht :


```
#!html

> Secondly, the pseudocount in this copy of Segway 'for training the mixture distribution weights' is set to 100--is there a particular reason for using 100? For reference, in the copy of GMM on the Segway bitbucket, it is set to 1.

No, we started off with a 100 and just kept it. We planned on testing out different pseudocounts but I don’t think we ever got to it.

I agree with Oscar -- I don't think there was any particular reason for using one value over another.
```
content.html:
segway-internal is not public, but as per @mlibbrecht :

> Secondly, the pseudocount in this copy of Segway 'for training the mixture distribution weights' is set to 100--is there a particular reason for using 100? For reference, in the copy of GMM on the Segway bitbucket, it is set to 1.

No, we started off with a 100 and just kept it. We planned on testing out different pseudocounts but I don’t think we ever got to it.

I agree with Oscar -- I don't think there was any particular reason for using one value over another.

content.raw:
"Currently varFloor is passed to GMTK only if either specified (with or without GMM) or it's not specified and mixture models is run (in which case, a default value of 0.001 is passed to ensure convergence)." Does that mean that no varFloor is used by default without GMM? That means that there are two default values for varFloor depending on whether or not GMM is used?

There is a comment in the code for the PR to address this.
content.html:
"Currently varFloor is passed to GMTK only if either specified (with or without GMM) or it's not specified and mixture models is run (in which case, a default value of 0.001 is passed to ensure convergence)." Does that mean that no varFloor is used by default without GMM? That means that there are two default values for varFloor depending on whether or not GMM is used?

There is a comment in the code for the PR to address this.

content.raw:
Yes, no varFloor is used by default without GMM.

No, no varFloor is passed at all if not specified and GMM is not used.

That is,

* If GMM && varFloor specified, specified value passed ```-varFloor spec```
* If GMM && no varFloor specified, default varFloor value of 0.001 passed ```-varFloor 0.001```
* If not GMM && varFloor specified, specified value passed ```-varFloor spec```
* If not GMM && no varFloor specified, no varFloor switch/value passed at all
content.html:
Yes, no varFloor is used by default without GMM.

No, no varFloor is passed at all if not specified and GMM is not used.

That is,

  • If GMM && varFloor specified, specified value passed -varFloor spec
  • If GMM && no varFloor specified, default varFloor value of 0.001 passed -varFloor 0.001
  • If not GMM && varFloor specified, specified value passed -varFloor spec
  • If not GMM && no varFloor specified, no varFloor switch/value passed at all

content.raw: Where does the default --varFloor of 0.001 come from? This assumes asinh normalization? Should this be computed based on the minimum variance found between tracks instead? What if an input track is all peaks? @mlibbrecht can you help answer this or if @rcwchan if you know please put the answer here.
content.html: Where does the default --varFloor of 0.001 come from? This assumes asinh normalization? Should this be computed based on the minimum variance found between tracks instead? What if an input track is all peaks? @mlibbrecht can you help answer this or if @rcwchan if you know please put the answer here.

content.raw: --varFloor should be used in conjunction with -zscore. In that case, a varFloor of 0.001 means that the variance cannot drop below 0.1% of the track's original variance, regardless of the normalization and of the original units. It would be reasonable to require --zscore when --varFloor is used. I think it would also be reasonable to make --zscore default.
content.html: --varFloor should be used in conjunction with -zscore. In that case, a varFloor of 0.001 means that the variance cannot drop below 0.1% of the track's original variance, regardless of the normalization and of the original units. It would be reasonable to require --zscore when --varFloor is used. I think it would also be reasonable to make --zscore default.

track autoScale=off description="segway 4-label segmentation of testtrack1, testtrack2" viewLimits=0:1 visibility=dense name=segway.74e2163cc2fb11e6a9eb989096b2d04e itemRgb=on
chr1	0	1000	3	1000	.	0	1000	231,41,138
chr1	1000	2000	1	1000	.	1000	2000	217,95,2
chr1	2000	3000	2	1000	.	2000	3000	117,112,179

Resulting segmentation:

track autoScale=off description="segway 4-label segmentation of testtrack1, testtrack2" viewLimits=0:1 visibility=dense name=segway.74e2163cc2fb11e6a9eb989096b2d04e itemRgb=on

chr1    5000    6000    1   1000    .   5000    6000    217,95,2

Note though, that 4/10 went to 100 rounds (with the rest somewhere in between).

content.raw: There is an inherient problem that, depending on the transformation (and possibly future transformations), different defaults should probably be used. A varFloor of 0.001 makes sense with --zscore on as you described it but it's much harder to figure out without the transformation. Having some rule of thumb in the documentation at least would be really helpful or a "smarter" pragmatic way of figuring out this value would also be very beneficial.
content.html: There is an inherient problem that, depending on the transformation (and possibly future transformations), different defaults should probably be used. A varFloor of 0.001 makes sense with --zscore on as you described it but it's much harder to figure out without the transformation. Having some rule of thumb in the documentation at least would be really helpful or a "smarter" pragmatic way of figuring out this value would also be very beneficial.

content.raw:
This is a very good point and one I was wondering myself. From ```segway-internal```:


```
#!html

>I think setting a variance floor is reasonable in all cases, although it will likely only matter for GMM. It should only come up in the edge case where EM tries to push the variance to 0, so the actual value should not matter as long as it is small and nonzero -- I think 0.001 is reasonable.

```
content.html:
This is a very good point and one I was wondering myself. From segway-internal:

>I think setting a variance floor is reasonable in all cases, although it will likely only matter for GMM. It should only come up in the edge case where EM tries to push the variance to 0, so the actual value should not matter as long as it is small and nonzero -- I think 0.001 is reasonable.

content.raw: Can you name this more specifically? I'm not certain what the "MIX" here refers to? It is a Gaussian mixture pseudo count?
content.html: Can you name this more specifically? I'm not certain what the "MIX" here refers to? It is a Gaussian mixture pseudo count?

content.raw:
Pseudocount for the DPMF table for the mixture of Gaussians. Corresponds to the 'dpmf_seg0_seg... dirichlet_num_mix_components...' table in the input.master and params files

Basically corresponds to a pseudocount for the weights of each mixture of Gaussians
content.html:
Pseudocount for the DPMF table for the mixture of Gaussians. Corresponds to the 'dpmf_seg0_seg... dirichlet_num_mix_components...' table in the input.master and params files

Basically corresponds to a pseudocount for the weights of each mixture of Gaussians

content.raw: A constant, default value of None might be unnecessary. If you're always checking if `self.var_floor` has been defined (i.e. not the default value), you can simply write `if self.var_floor` instead of `if self.var_floor == VAR_FLOOR_DEFAULT`. This happens a lot throughout the code.
content.html: A constant, default value of None might be unnecessary. If you're always checking if self.var_floor has been defined (i.e. not the default value), you can simply write if self.var_floor instead of if self.var_floor == VAR_FLOOR_DEFAULT. This happens a lot throughout the code.
